description: Mutual or one-way confidentiality agreements for protecting sensitive business information

clauses.title: Confidentiality Duration
clauses.plainDescription: How long must the receiving party keep information confidential after the agreement ends?
clauses.legalContext: Longer durations provide more protection but may be harder to enforce. Trade secrets may warrant perpetual protection. Courts generally find 2-5 year terms reasonable for most business information.

options.label: 2 Years
options.plainDescription: Confidentiality obligations last 2 years after termination - standard for most business discussions.
consPartyA: Information may still be valuable when protection ends
consPartyB: May need to track expiration dates
options.legalText: The confidentiality obligations in this Agreement will survive termination or expiration for a period of two (2) years.

options.label: 3 Years
options.plainDescription: Confidentiality obligations last 3 years - balanced protection for sensitive industries.
consPartyA: May seem aggressive in some industries
options.legalText: The confidentiality obligations in this Agreement will survive termination or expiration for a period of three (3) years.

options.label: 5 Years
options.plainDescription: Confidentiality obligations last 5 years - strong protection for highly sensitive information.
options.legalText: The confidentiality obligations in this Agreement will survive termination or expiration for a period of five (5) years.

options.label: Perpetual (Trade Secrets)
options.plainDescription: Confidentiality obligations continue indefinitely for information qualifying as trade secrets.
consPartyA: May require proving trade secret status
options.legalText: The confidentiality obligations in this Agreement with respect to information qualifying as a trade secret under applicable law will survive indefinitely.

clauses.title: Permitted Disclosures
clauses.plainDescription: Under what circumstances can the receiving party share confidential information with others?
clauses.legalContext: Broader permitted disclosures give the receiving party flexibility but reduce the disclosing party's control. Most agreements allow disclosure to professional advisors; the question is how much further to extend.

options.label: Strict (Legal Requirement Only)
options.plainDescription: Only disclose when legally compelled by court order or government authority, with prior notice to the disclosing party.
options.legalText: The Receiving Party may only disclose Confidential Information if required by law, court order, or governmental authority, provided that the Receiving Party gives the Disclosing Party prompt written notice to allow the Disclosing Party to seek protective measures.

options.label: Standard (+ Professional Advisors)
options.plainDescription: Legal requirements plus disclosure to lawyers, accountants, and financial advisors bound by professional confidentiality duties.
options.legalText: The Receiving Party may disclose Confidential Information: (a) if required by law, court order, or governmental authority, provided prompt notice is given; (b) to professional legal or financial advisors bound by duties of confidentiality.

options.label: Extended (+ Employees & Contractors)
options.plainDescription: Includes advisors plus employees and contractors who need to know for the business purpose, bound by written confidentiality agreements.
options.legalText: The Receiving Party may disclose Confidential Information to: (a) legal requirements with notice; (b) professional advisors; (c) employees and contractors with a need to know, provided they are bound by written confidentiality obligations at least as protective as this Agreement.

options.label: Broad (+ Affiliates & Partners)
options.plainDescription: Includes all above plus affiliated companies and potential business partners under written confidentiality terms.
options.legalText: The Receiving Party may disclose Confidential Information to: (a) legal requirements with notice; (b) professional advisors; (c) employees and contractors with need to know; (d) affiliates and potential business partners who agree in writing to confidentiality terms at least as protective as this Agreement.

clauses.title: Definition of Confidential Information
clauses.plainDescription: What types of information are protected under this agreement? How is confidential information identified?
clauses.legalContext: A broad definition protects more information but may be harder to enforce. A narrow definition with marking requirements provides clarity but may miss oral disclosures.

options.label: Narrow (Marked Information Only)
options.plainDescription: Only information explicitly marked as 'Confidential' or 'Proprietary' at the time of disclosure is protected.
options.legalText: "Confidential Information" means any information disclosed by the Disclosing Party that is marked as "confidential" or "proprietary" at the time of disclosure.

options.label: Standard (Marked + Reasonable Understanding)
options.plainDescription: Information that is marked as confidential OR would reasonably be understood to be confidential given its nature.
consPartyB: May need to ask about specific items
options.legalText: "Confidential Information" means any information disclosed by the Disclosing Party that: (a) is marked as "confidential" or "proprietary"; or (b) would reasonably be understood to be confidential given its nature or the circumstances of disclosure.

options.label: Broad (All Non-Public Information)
options.plainDescription: All non-public information disclosed by either party, regardless of marking, is considered confidential.
options.legalText: "Confidential Information" means any non-public information disclosed by the Disclosing Party to the Receiving Party, whether orally, in writing, or in any other form, regardless of whether marked as confidential.

clauses.title: Return or Destruction of Information
clauses.plainDescription: What happens to confidential information when the agreement ends? Must it be returned, destroyed, or can copies be retained?
clauses.legalContext: Complete destruction provides maximum protection but may conflict with legal retention requirements. Allowing archival copies is practical but extends obligations.

options.label: Strict (Return or Destroy All)
options.plainDescription: All confidential information must be returned or destroyed within 10 business days, with written certification.
options.legalText: Upon termination or expiration, the Receiving Party must return or destroy all Confidential Information within ten (10) business days and certify destruction in writing.

options.label: Standard (With Legal Archive Exception)
options.plainDescription: Return or destroy all information, but may retain one archival copy for legal compliance purposes.
options.legalText: Upon termination, the Receiving Party must return or destroy all Confidential Information within thirty (30) days, except that one archival copy may be retained solely for legal compliance purposes, which remains subject to this Agreement.

options.label: Flexible (With Backup Exception)
options.plainDescription: Return or destroy accessible copies, but automatic backup copies may be retained if not accessed except for recovery.
options.legalText: Upon termination, the Receiving Party must return or destroy all readily accessible Confidential Information within thirty (30) days. Copies in routine backup systems may be retained provided they are not accessed except for backup recovery purposes and remain subject to confidentiality obligations.

clauses.title: Dispute Resolution
clauses.plainDescription: How and where will disputes about this agreement be resolved? You can choose courts in the governing law jurisdiction, courts elsewhere, or private arbitration.
clauses.legalContext: The forum for disputes is negotiable even though the governing law is fixed. Court litigation is public with appeal rights. Arbitration is private and faster but typically final. The choice of forum can significantly impact cost and convenience.

options.label: Default Courts (Per Governing Law)
options.plainDescription: Disputes resolved in courts of the governing law jurisdiction: San Francisco (California), London (England & Wales), or Madrid (Spain).
consPartyA: May be inconvenient for one party
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be resolved exclusively in the state and federal courts located in the jurisdiction of the governing law. Each Party irrevocably submits to the exclusive jurisdiction of such courts.

options.label: Delaware Courts (Neutral - US)
options.plainDescription: Disputes resolved in Delaware courts, known for sophisticated commercial law and business-friendly judiciary.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be resolved exclusively in the Court of Chancery of the State of Delaware (or, if such court lacks jurisdiction, the state and federal courts located in Delaware). Each Party irrevocably submits to the exclusive jurisdiction of such courts.

options.label: JAMS Arbitration
options.plainDescription: Private arbitration under JAMS (Judicial Arbitration and Mediation Services) rules - popular with technology companies and startups.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by binding arbitration administered by JAMS under its Comprehensive Arbitration Rules. The arbitration will be conducted by one arbitrator in the seat of the governing law jurisdiction. The arbitrator's award is final and binding.

options.label: ICC Arbitration
options.plainDescription: International arbitration under ICC (International Chamber of Commerce) rules - the gold standard for cross-border disputes.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by arbitration under the Rules of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce. The arbitration will be conducted by one arbitrator, with the seat in the capital of the governing law jurisdiction. The award is final and binding.

options.label: AAA Arbitration
options.plainDescription: Arbitration under AAA (American Arbitration Association) Commercial Rules - well-established with extensive arbitrator network.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by arbitration administered by the American Arbitration Association under its Commercial Arbitration Rules. The arbitration will be conducted by one arbitrator in the seat of the governing law jurisdiction.

options.label: LCIA Arbitration
options.plainDescription: Arbitration under LCIA (London Court of International Arbitration) rules - preferred for UK and international commercial disputes.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by arbitration under the LCIA Rules. The arbitration will be conducted by a sole arbitrator appointed by the LCIA Court. The seat of arbitration will be London, United Kingdom.

clauses.title: Remedies for Breach
clauses.plainDescription: What remedies are available if a party breaches the agreement? Can the injured party seek injunctive relief without proving damages?
clauses.legalContext: Injunctive relief allows courts to stop ongoing breaches quickly. Without explicit provisions, proving irreparable harm can be difficult.

options.label: Standard (Injunctive Relief Available)
options.plainDescription: The disclosing party may seek injunctive relief for breach without proving actual damages, acknowledging confidential information is unique.
prosPartyA: No need to prove monetary harm
options.legalText: Each Party acknowledges that Confidential Information is valuable and unique, and that unauthorized disclosure may cause irreparable harm. The Disclosing Party is entitled to seek injunctive relief without proving actual damages, in addition to other legal remedies.

options.label: Enhanced (+ No Bond Requirement)
options.plainDescription: Injunctive relief available without proving damages AND without requirement to post a bond.
consPartyB: Easier for counterparty to get injunction
options.legalText: The Disclosing Party is entitled to seek injunctive relief without proving actual damages and without the requirement to post a bond, to the extent permitted by applicable law, in addition to other legal remedies.

options.label: Balanced (All Legal Remedies)
options.plainDescription: Either party may pursue any legal remedies available, including damages and injunctive relief where appropriate.
consPartyA: May need to prove irreparable harm
options.legalText: Each Party reserves all rights and remedies available at law or in equity for any breach of this Agreement, including the right to seek monetary damages and injunctive relief where appropriate.

clauses.title: Agreement Term
clauses.plainDescription: How long will this NDA remain in effect? When can either party terminate it?
clauses.legalContext: The agreement term is different from confidentiality duration. The term covers when new disclosures can be made; confidentiality obligations on already-disclosed information survive termination.

options.label: 1 Year
options.plainDescription: Agreement remains in effect for 1 year, with option to extend by mutual agreement.
options.legalText: This Agreement begins on the Effective Date and continues for one (1) year, unless terminated earlier by either Party giving thirty (30) days' written notice.

options.label: 2 Years
options.plainDescription: Agreement remains in effect for 2 years, providing a reasonable window for business discussions.
options.legalText: This Agreement begins on the Effective Date and continues for two (2) years, unless terminated earlier by either Party giving thirty (30) days' written notice.

options.label: 3 Years
options.plainDescription: Agreement remains in effect for 3 years, suitable for complex or long-term business discussions.
options.legalText: This Agreement begins on the Effective Date and continues for three (3) years, unless terminated earlier by either Party giving sixty (60) days' written notice.

clauses.title: Non-Solicitation of Employees
clauses.plainDescription: Should the parties agree not to recruit or hire each other's employees during and after the NDA term?
clauses.legalContext: Non-solicitation provisions are common in NDAs where parties will have significant contact. However, they may be unenforceable in some jurisdictions like California under Business & Professions Code 16600.

options.label: No Non-Solicitation
options.plainDescription: No restrictions on hiring or recruiting each other's employees.
options.legalText: [No non-solicitation provision included]

CALIFORNIA.note: Recommended for California - non-solicitation provisions are generally unenforceable

options.label: During Agreement Term Only
options.plainDescription: Parties agree not to solicit each other's employees while the NDA is in effect, but may do so after termination.
options.legalText: During the term of this Agreement, neither Party will directly solicit for employment any employee of the other Party with whom it has had contact in connection with the Purpose.

CALIFORNIA.warning: California courts generally refuse to enforce employee non-solicitation provisions under Business & Professions Code 16600. This provision may be unenforceable.

ENGLAND_WALES.note: Enforceable if reasonable in scope and duration

SPAIN.note: Subject to Spanish labor law protections

options.label: Extended (Term + 1 Year After)
options.plainDescription: Non-solicitation applies during the agreement term and for 1 year after termination.
options.legalText: During the term of this Agreement and for one (1) year thereafter, neither Party will directly solicit for employment any employee of the other Party with whom it has had contact in connection with the Purpose.

CALIFORNIA.warning: Post-termination non-solicitation provisions are unenforceable in California under Business & Professions Code 16600. Select 'No Non-Solicitation' instead.

ENGLAND_WALES.note: Must be reasonable - courts may reduce excessive duration

SPAIN.note: Subject to reasonableness review under Spanish law

clauses.title: Assignment Rights
clauses.plainDescription: Can either party transfer their rights and obligations under this NDA to another entity?
clauses.legalContext: Assignment provisions matter for M&A situations. Restricting assignment protects against unwanted disclosure to acquiring companies.

options.label: No Assignment Allowed
options.plainDescription: Neither party may assign this agreement to any third party without written consent.
prosPartyA: Maximum control over who receives information
prosPartyB: Know exactly who the counterparty is
options.legalText: Neither Party may assign or transfer this Agreement without the prior written consent of the other Party. Any attempted assignment without consent is void.

options.label: Affiliates Only
options.plainDescription: Assignment allowed to affiliates (entities under common control) without consent, but not to third parties.
options.legalText: Neither Party may assign this Agreement without consent, except to an affiliate under common control upon written notice. The assigning Party remains responsible for the affiliate's compliance.

options.label: Affiliates + Merger/Acquisition
options.plainDescription: Assignment allowed to affiliates or in connection with a merger, acquisition, or sale of substantially all assets.
options.legalText: Neither Party may assign this Agreement without consent, except: (a) to an affiliate; or (b) in connection with a merger, acquisition, or sale of substantially all assets, upon written notice to the other Party.
